_prev_prog_3.Description: Columbine Vineyards Plant 2 has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHA's "Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials" standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, "Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials," and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Columbine Vineyards utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant in their cold storage facility located east of Delano, California.  Since the refrigeration system handles more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, Columbine Vineyards has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for the ammonia based refrigeration processes.  



As part of the PSM program, Columbine Vineyards has completed process hazard analyses, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on the refrigeration system, established a pre-startup safety review, and developed a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia equipment.  In addition to plant personnel monitoring the operation of the refrigeration systems on a daily basis, Columbine Vineyards has implemented a preventative maintenance program to ensure that the refrigeration system maintained in good operating condition.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an accidental release.



Personnel from Columbine Vineyards monitor the daily operation of the refrigeration system.  All major service, maintenance, and repairs to the ammonia refrigeration system are contracted to a qualified licensed refrigeration contractor specializing in ammonia refrigeration.  Utilizing an experienced qualified contractor to perform routine service, maintenance, and repairs ensures that the equipment is in excellent operating condition. 



While it is Columbine Vineyards objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the cold storage facility precludes emergency response operations.  As such, an emergency action plan has been prepared for Columbine Vineyards and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.

 

Columbine Vineyards has developed a detailed Compliance Audit Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with the PSM a

nd RMP regulations.  At least every three years, Columbine Vineyards will audit these programs and any findings of noncompliance will be documented and responded to and the deficiencies will be corrected.



2. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 



The Columbine Vineyards owns and operates a cold storage facility located at 33787 Cecil Avenue.  Delano is the closest city to the Columbine Vineyards cold storage facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant that provides process cooling for the Columbine Vineyards cold storage facility.  



The original Cecil Avenue Cold Storage facility was constructed in the 1940s.  In 1992, the ammonia based refrigeration system was substantially modernized when the cold storage facility was expanded.  The ammonia refrigeration system was expanded again in 1999 and remodeled in 2007.  The refrigeration system currently consists of the following major components:



    -    Four compressors 

    -    Two evaporative condensers in ammonia service

    -    A high pressure receiver 

    -    Low suction accumulator

    -    Liquid ammonia transfer system

    -    Five pre-cool rooms (10 zones)

    -    Nine cold storage rooms (15 zones)

    -    Direct expansion evaporators (hallway)



During normal operation, the anhydrous ammonia is distributed throughout the refrigeration system.  However, during major maintenance activities, the entire refrigeration system can be A?pumped downA? to evacuate the ammonia from the system and store it in the high pressure receiver.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the outdoor high pressure receiver is 61,000 pounds. 



For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, 40 CFR Part 68 and the CalARP regulations define the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, is being im

plemented at Columbine Vineyards to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:



-    Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.



-    Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) have been completed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.



-    Written operating procedures have been developed and will be reviewed at least annually.



-    Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility have been developed and implemented.



-    Each employee involved in operating the ammonia system has received initial training and refresher training at least every three years.



-    Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.



-    A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.



-    Pre-startup safety reviews will be performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.



-    Audits will be conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the RMP regulations.



-    Incident investigation procedures have been established.



-    A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.



-    Hot work permits will be issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system.



-    A Contractor Safety Policy has been developed and implemented.





4. Five-Year Accident History



The Columbine Vineyards cold storage facility east of Delano, California has not had any accidental releases in the last five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off

site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





5. Emergency Response Program



Columbine Vineyards has established an emergency action plan and a chain of command to respond to emergencies and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.  However, an emergency response program does not need to be developed for the facility since Columbine VineyardsA? employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.



6.Planned Changes To Improve Safety



Through the accidental release prevention program, Columbine Vineyards regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety.  Currently, Columbine Vineyards does not have any changes planned for the anhydrous ammonia-based refrigeration processes to improve safety.
